column2: Chapter VI.

column2: For Awhile A Very Obscure One

column2: And Ivan, on parting from Alyosha, went home to Fyodor Pavlovitch's house. But, strange to say, he was overcome by insufferable depression, which grew greater at every step he took towards the house.
column3: And Ivan, on parting from Alyosha, went home to Fyodor Pavlovitch's house. But, strange to say, he was overcome by insufferable depression, which grew greater at every step he took towards the house.

column2: There was nothing strange in his being depressed; what was strange was that Ivan could not have said what was the cause of it.
column3: There was nothing strange in his being depressed; what was strange was that Ivan could not have said what was the cause of it.

column2: He had often been depressed before, and there was nothing surprising at his feeling so at such a moment, when he had broken off with everything that had brought him here, and was preparing that day to make a new start and enter upon a new, unknown future.
column3: He had often been depressed before, and there was nothing surprising at his feeling so at such a moment, when he had broken off with everything that had brought him here, and was preparing that day to make a new start and enter upon a new, unknown future.

column2: He would again be as solitary as ever, and though he had great hopes, and great--too great--expectations from life, he could not have given any definite account of his hopes, his expectations, or even his desires.
column3: He would again be as solitary as ever, and though he had great hopes, and great-too great-expectations from life, he could not have given any definite account of his hopes, his expectations, or even his desires.

column2: For so many years I've been silent with the whole world and not deigned to speak, and all of a sudden I reel off a rigmarole like that." column2: Some person or thing seemed to be standing out somewhere, just as something will sometimes obtrude itself upon the eye, and though one may be so busy with work or conversation that for a long time one does not notice it, yet it irritates and almost torments one till at last one realizes, and removes the offending object, often quite a trifling and ridiculous one--some article left about in the wrong place, a handkerchief on the floor, a book not replaced on the shelf, and so on.

column2: At last, feeling very cross and ill-humored, Ivan arrived home, and suddenly, about fifteen paces from the garden gate, he guessed what was fretting and worrying him.
column3: At last, feeling very cross and ill humored, Ivan arrived home, and suddenly, about fifteen paces from the garden gate, he guessed what was fretting and worrying him.

column3: He always spoke in a tone that suggested that those two had some kind of compact, some secret between them, that had at some time been expressed on both sides, only known to them and beyond the comprehension of those around them.

column3: I'm bound to admit the fact, Smerdyakov drawled with pedantic composure, "that I have a secret with Fyodor Pavlovitch in this business.

column2: As you know yourself (if only you do know it) he has for several days past locked himself in as soon as night or even evening comes on.
column3: As you know yourself (if only you do know it) he has for several days past locked himself in as soon as night or even evening comes on.

column2: Of late you've been going upstairs to your room early every evening, and yesterday you did not come down at all, and so perhaps you don't know how carefully he has begun to lock himself in at night, and even if Grigory Vassilyevitch comes to the door he won't open to him till he hears his voice.
column3: Of late you've been going upstairs to your room early every evening, and yesterday you did not come down at all, and so perhaps you don't know how carefully he has begun to lock himself in at night, and even if Grigory Vassilyevitch comes to the door he won't open to him till he hears his voice.

column2: But Grigory Vassilyevitch does not come, because I wait upon him alone in his room now.
column3: But Grigory Vassilyevitch does not come, because I wait upon him alone in his room now.

column2: That's the arrangement he made himself ever since this to-do with Agrafena Alexandrovna began.
column3: That's the arrangement he made himself ever since this to do with Agrafena Alexandrovna began.

column2: But at night, by his orders, I go away to the lodge so that I don't get to sleep till midnight, but am on the watch, getting up and walking about the yard, waiting for Agrafena Alexandrovna to come.
column3: But at night, by his orders, I go away to the lodge so that I don't get to sleep till midnight, but am on the watch, getting up and walking about the yard, waiting for Agrafena Alexandrovna to come.

column2: For the last few days he's been perfectly frantic expecting her. What he argues is, she is afraid of him, Dmitri Fyodorovitch (Mitya, as he calls him), 'and so,' says he, 'she'll come the back-way, late at night, to me.
column3: For the last few days he's been perfectly frantic expecting her. What he argues is, she is afraid of him, Dmitri Fyodorovitch (Mitya, as he calls him), 'and so,' says he, 'she'll come the back way, late at night, to me.

column2: You look out for her,' says he, 'till midnight and later; and if she does come, you run up and knock at my door or at the window from the garden.
column3: You look out for her,' says he, 'till midnight and later; and if she does come, you run up and knock at my door or at the window from the garden.

column2: Knock at first twice, rather gently, and then three times more quickly, then,' says he, 'I shall understand at once that she has come, and will open the door to you quietly.' Another signal he gave me in case anything unexpected happens.
column3: Knock at first twice, rather gently, and then three times more quickly, then,' says he, 'I shall understand at once that she has come, and will open the door to you quietly.' Another signal he gave me in case anything unexpected happens.

column2: At first, two knocks, and then, after an interval, another much louder.
column3: At first, two knocks, and then, after an interval, another much louder.

column2: Then he will understand that something has happened suddenly and that I must see him, and he will open to me so that I can go and speak to him.
column3: Then he will understand that something has happened suddenly and that I must see him, and he will open to me so that I can go and speak to him.

column2: That's all in case Agrafena Alexandrovna can't come herself, but sends a message.
column3: That's all in case Agrafena Alexandrovna can't come herself, but sends a message.

column2: Besides, Dmitri Fyodorovitch might come, too, so I must let him know he is near.
column3: Besides, Dmitri Fyodorovitch might come, too, so I must let him know he is near.

column2: His honor is awfully afraid of Dmitri Fyodorovitch, so that even if Agrafena Alexandrovna had come and were locked in with him, and Dmitri Fyodorovitch were to turn up anywhere near at the time, I should be bound to let him know at once, knocking three times.
column3: His honor is awfully afraid of Dmitri Fyodorovitch, so that even if Agrafena Alexandrovna had come and were locked in with him, and Dmitri Fyodorovitch were to turn up anywhere near at the time, I should be bound to let him know at once, knocking three times.

column2: So that the first signal of five knocks means Agrafena Alexandrovna has come, while the second signal of three knocks means 'something important to tell you.' His honor has shown me them several times and explained them.
column3: So that the first signal of five knocks means Agrafena Alexandrovna has come, while the second signal of three knocks means 'something important to tell you.' His honor has shown me them several times and explained them.

column2: And as in the whole universe no one knows of these signals but myself and his honor, so he'd open the door without the slightest hesitation and without calling out (he is awfully afraid of calling out aloud).
column3: And as in the whole universe no one knows of these signals but myself and his honor, so he'd open the door without the slightest hesitation and without calling out (he is awfully afraid of calling out aloud).

column2: Well, those signals are known to Dmitri Fyodorovitch too, now."
column3: Well, those signals are known to Dmitri Fyodorovitch too, now."

column2: How are they known?	How are they known?
column3: true

column2: Did you tell him?
column3: Did you tell him?

column2: How dared you tell him?"
column3: How dared you tell him?"

column2: It was through fright I did it.	It was through fright I did it.
column3: false

column2: How could I dare to keep it back from him?
column3: How could I dare to keep it back from him?

column2: Dmitri Fyodorovitch kept persisting every day, 'You are deceiving me, you are hiding something from me!
column3: Dmitri Fyodorovitch kept persisting every day, 'You are deceiving me, you are hiding something from me!

column2: I'll break both your legs for you.' So I told him those secret signals that he might see my slavish devotion, and might be satisfied that I was not deceiving him, but was telling him all I could."
column3: I'll break both your legs for you.' So I told him those secret signals that he might see my slavish devotion, and might be satisfied that I was not deceiving him, but was telling him all I could."

column2: If you think that he'll make use of those signals and try to get in, don't let him in.
column3: If you think that he'll make use of those signals and try to get in, don't let him in.

column2: But if I should be laid up with a fit, how can I prevent him coming in then, even if I dared prevent him, knowing how desperate he is?
column3: But if I should be laid up with a fit, how can I prevent him coming in then, even if I dared prevent him, knowing how desperate he is?

column2: Hang it!	Hang it!
column3: true

column2: How can you be so sure you are going to have a fit, confound you?
column3: How can you be so sure you are going to have a fit, confound you?

column2: Are you laughing at me?"
column3: Are you laughing at me?"

column2: How could I dare laugh at you?	How could I dare laugh at you?
column3: false

column2: I am in no laughing humor with this fear on me.
column3: I am in no laughing humor with this fear on me.

column2: I feel I am going to have a fit.
column3: I feel I am going to have a fit.

column2: I have a presentiment.
column3: I have a presentiment.

column2: Fright alone will bring it on."
column3: Fright alone will bring it on."

column2: Confound it!	Confound it!
column3: true

column2: If you are laid up, Grigory will be on the watch.
column3: If you are laid up, Grigory will be on the watch.

column2: Let Grigory know beforehand; he will be sure not to let him in."
column3: Let Grigory know beforehand; he will be sure not to let him in."

column2: I should never dare to tell Grigory Vassilyevitch about the signals without orders from my master.	I should never dare to tell Grigory Vassilyevitch about the signals without orders from my master.
column3: true

column2: And as for Grigory Vassilyevitch hearing him and not admitting him, he has been ill ever since yesterday, and Marfa Ignatyevna intends to give him medicine to-morrow.
column3: And as for Grigory Vassilyevitch hearing him and not admitting him, he has been ill ever since yesterday, and Marfa Ignatyevna intends to give him medicine to morrow.

column2: They've just arranged it.
column3: They've just arranged it.

column2: It's a very strange remedy of hers.
column3: It's a very strange remedy of hers.

column2: Marfa Ignatyevna knows of a preparation and always keeps it.
column3: Marfa Ignatyevna knows of a preparation and always keeps it.

column2: It's a strong thing made from some herb. She has the secret of it, and she always gives it to Grigory Vassilyevitch three times a year when his lumbago's so bad he is almost paralyzed by it. Then she takes a towel, wets it with the stuff, and rubs his whole back for half an hour till it's quite red and swollen, and what's left in the bottle she gives him to drink with a special prayer; but not quite all, for on such occasions she leaves some for herself, and drinks it herself. And as they never take strong drink, I assure you they both drop asleep at once and sleep sound a very long time.
column3: It's a strong thing made from some herb. She has the secret of it, and she always gives it to Grigory Vassilyevitch three times a year when his lumbago's so bad he is almost paralyzed by it. Then she takes a towel, wets it with the stuff, and rubs his whole back for half an hour till it's quite red and swollen, and what's left in the bottle she gives him to drink with a special prayer; but not quite all, for on such occasions she leaves some for herself, and drinks it herself. And as they never take strong drink, I assure you they both drop asleep at once and sleep sound a very long time.

column2: And when Grigory Vassilyevitch wakes up he is perfectly well after it, but Marfa Ignatyevna always has a headache from it.
column3: And when Grigory Vassilyevitch wakes up he is perfectly well after it, but Marfa Ignatyevna always has a headache from it.

column2: So, if Marfa Ignatyevna carries out her intention to-morrow, they won't hear anything and hinder Dmitri Fyodorovitch. They'll be asleep."
column3: So, if Marfa Ignatyevna carries out her intention to morrow, they won't hear anything and hinder Dmitri Fyodorovitch. They'll be asleep."

column2: What a rigmarole!	What a rigmarole!
column3: true

column2: And it all seems to happen at once, as though it were planned.
column3: And it all seems to happen at once, as though it were planned.

column2: You'll have a fit and they'll both be unconscious," cried Ivan. "But aren't you trying to arrange it so?" broke from him suddenly, and he frowned threateningly.
column3: You'll have a fit and they'll both be unconscious," cried Ivan. "But aren't you trying to arrange it so?" broke from him suddenly, and he frowned threateningly.

column2: How could I?...	How could I?...
column3: true

column2: And why should I, when it all depends on Dmitri Fyodorovitch and his plans?...
column3: And why should I, when it all depends on Dmitri Fyodorovitch and his plans?...

column2: If he means to do anything, he'll do it; but if not, I shan't be thrusting him upon his father."
column3: If he means to do anything, he'll do it; but if not, I shan't be thrusting him upon his father."

column2: And why should he go to father, especially on the sly, if, as you say yourself, Agrafena Alexandrovna won't come at all? Ivan went on, turning white with anger.
column3: And why should he go to father, especially on the sly, if, as you say yourself, Agrafena Alexandrovna won't come at all? Ivan went on, turning white with anger.

column2: You say that yourself, and all the while I've been here, I've felt sure it was all the old man's fancy, and the creature won't come to him.	You say that yourself, and all the while I've been here, I've felt sure it was all the old man's fancy, and the creature won't come to him.
column3: true

column2: Why should Dmitri break in on him if she doesn't come? Speak, I want to know what you are thinking!"
column3: Why should Dmitri break in on him if she doesn't come? Speak, I want to know what you are thinking!"

column2: You know yourself why he'll come.	You know yourself why he'll come.
column3: true

column2: What's the use of what I think?
column3: What's the use of what I think?

column2: His honor will come simply because he is in a rage or suspicious on account of my illness perhaps, and he'll dash in, as he did yesterday through impatience to search the rooms, to see whether she hasn't escaped him on the sly.
column3: His honor will come simply because he is in a rage or suspicious on account of my illness perhaps, and he'll dash in, as he did yesterday through impatience to search the rooms, to see whether she hasn't escaped him on the sly.

column2: He is perfectly well aware, too, that Fyodor Pavlovitch has a big envelope with three thousand roubles in it, tied up with ribbon and sealed with three seals.
column3: He is perfectly well aware, too, that Fyodor Pavlovitch has a big envelope with three thousand roubles in it, tied up with ribbon and sealed with three seals.

column2: On it is written in his own hand, 'To my angel Grushenka, if she will come,' to which he added three days later, 'for my little chicken.' There's no knowing what that might do."
column3: On it is written in his own hand, 'To my angel Grushenka, if she will come,' to which he added three days later, 'for my little chicken.' There's no knowing what that might do."

column2: Nonsense! cried Ivan, almost beside himself.
column3: Nonsense! cried Ivan, almost beside himself.

column2: Dmitri won't come to steal money and kill my father to do it.	Dmitri won't come to steal money and kill my father to do it.
column3: true

column2: He might have killed him yesterday on account of Grushenka, like the frantic, savage fool he is, but he won't steal."
column3: He might have killed him yesterday on account of Grushenka, like the frantic, savage fool he is, but he won't steal."

column2: He is in very great need of money now--the greatest need, Ivan Fyodorovitch.	He is in very great need of money now-the greatest need, Ivan Fyodorovitch.
column3: false

column2: You don't know in what need he is," Smerdyakov explained, with perfect composure and remarkable distinctness.
column3: You don't know in what need he is," Smerdyakov explained, with perfect composure and remarkable distinctness.

column2: He looks on that three thousand as his own, too.	He looks on that three thousand as his own, too.
column3: true

column2: He said so to me himself.
column3: He said so to me himself.

column2: 'My father still owes me just three thousand,' he said.
column3: 'My father still owes me just three thousand,' he said.

column2: And besides that, consider, Ivan Fyodorovitch, there is something else perfectly true.
column3: And besides that, consider, Ivan Fyodorovitch, there is something else perfectly true.

column2: It's as good as certain, so to say, that Agrafena Alexandrovna will force him, if only she cares to, to marry her--the master himself, I mean, Fyodor Pavlovitch--if only she cares to, and of course she may care to.
column3: It's as good as certain, so to say, that Agrafena Alexandrovna will force him, if only she cares to, to marry her-the master himself, I mean, Fyodor Pavlovitch-if only she cares to, and of course she may care to.

column2: All I've said is that she won't come, but maybe she's looking for more than that--I mean to be mistress here.
column3: All I've said is that she won't come, but maybe she's looking for more than that-I mean to be mistress here.

column2: I know myself that Samsonov, her merchant, was laughing with her about it, telling her quite openly that it would not be at all a stupid thing to do.
column3: I know myself that Samsonov, her merchant, was laughing with her about it, telling her quite openly that it would not be at all a stupid thing to do.

column2: And she's got plenty of sense.
column3: And she's got plenty of sense.

column2: She wouldn't marry a beggar like Dmitri Fyodorovitch.
column3: She wouldn't marry a beggar like Dmitri Fyodorovitch.

column2: So, taking that into consideration, Ivan Fyodorovitch, reflect that then neither Dmitri Fyodorovitch nor yourself and your brother, Alexey Fyodorovitch, would have anything after the master's death, not a rouble, for Agrafena Alexandrovna would marry him simply to get hold of the whole, all the money there is.
column3: So, taking that into consideration, Ivan Fyodorovitch, reflect that then neither Dmitri Fyodorovitch nor yourself and your brother, Alexey Fyodorovitch, would have anything after the master's death, not a rouble, for Agrafena Alexandrovna would marry him simply to get hold of the whole, all the money there is.

column2: But if your father were to die now, there'd be some forty thousand for sure, even for Dmitri Fyodorovitch whom he hates so, for he's made no will....
column3: But if your father were to die now, there'd be some forty thousand for sure, even for Dmitri Fyodorovitch whom he hates so, for he's made no will....

column2: Dmitri Fyodorovitch knows all that very well."
column3: Dmitri Fyodorovitch knows all that very well."

column2: A sort of shudder passed over Ivan's face.
column3: A sort of shudder passed over Ivan's face.

column2: He suddenly flushed.
column3: He suddenly flushed.

column2: Then why on earth, he suddenly interrupted Smerdyakov, "do you advise me to go to Tchermashnya?
column3: Then why on earth, he suddenly interrupted Smerdyakov, "do you advise me to go to Tchermashnya?

column2: What did you mean by that?
column3: What did you mean by that?

column2: If I go away, you see what will happen here." Ivan drew his breath with difficulty.
column3: If I go away, you see what will happen here." Ivan drew his breath with difficulty.

column2: Precisely so, said Smerdyakov, softly and reasonably, watching Ivan intently, however.
column3: Precisely so, said Smerdyakov, softly and reasonably, watching Ivan intently, however.

column2: What do you mean by 'precisely so'? Ivan questioned him, with a menacing light in his eyes, restraining himself with difficulty.
column3: What do you mean by 'precisely so'? Ivan questioned him, with a menacing light in his eyes, restraining himself with difficulty.

column2: I spoke because I felt sorry for you.	I spoke because I felt sorry for you.
column3: true

column2: If I were in your place I should simply throw it all up ... rather than stay on in such a position," answered Smerdyakov, with the most candid air looking at Ivan's flashing eyes.
column3: If I were in your place I should simply throw it all up ... rather than stay on in such a position," answered Smerdyakov, with the most candid air looking at Ivan's flashing eyes.

column2: They were both silent.
column3: They were both silent.

column2: You seem to be a perfect idiot, and what's more ... an awful scoundrel, too. Ivan rose suddenly from the bench.
column3: You seem to be a perfect idiot, and what's more ... an awful scoundrel, too. Ivan rose suddenly from the bench.

column2: He was about to pass straight through the gate, but he stopped short and turned to Smerdyakov.
column3: He was about to pass straight through the gate, but he stopped short and turned to Smerdyakov.

column2: Something strange followed.
column3: Something strange followed.

column2: Ivan, in a sudden paroxysm, bit his lip, clenched his fists, and, in another minute, would have flung himself on Smerdyakov.
column3: Ivan, in a sudden paroxysm, bit his lip, clenched his fists, and, in another minute, would have flung himself on Smerdyakov.

column2: The latter, anyway, noticed it at the same moment, started, and shrank back. But the moment passed without mischief to Smerdyakov, and Ivan turned in silence, as it seemed in perplexity, to the gate.
column3: The latter, anyway, noticed it at the same moment, started, and shrank back. But the moment passed without mischief to Smerdyakov, and Ivan turned in silence, as it seemed in perplexity, to the gate.

column2: I am going away to Moscow to-morrow, if you care to know--early to-morrow morning.	I am going away to Moscow to morrow, if you care to know-early to morrow morning.
column3: true

column2: That's all!" he suddenly said aloud angrily, and wondered himself afterwards what need there was to say this then to Smerdyakov.
column3: That's all!" he suddenly said aloud angrily, and wondered himself afterwards what need there was to say this then to Smerdyakov.

column2: That's the best thing you can do, he responded, as though he had expected to hear it; "except that you can always be telegraphed for from Moscow, if anything should happen here."
column3: That's the best thing you can do, he responded, as though he had expected to hear it; "except that you can always be telegraphed for from Moscow, if anything should happen here."

column2: Ivan stopped again, and again turned quickly to Smerdyakov.
column3: Ivan stopped again, and again turned quickly to Smerdyakov.

column2: But a change had passed over him, too.
column3: But a change had passed over him, too.

column2: All his familiarity and carelessness had completely disappeared.
column3: All his familiarity and carelessness had completely disappeared.

column2: His face expressed attention and expectation, intent but timid and cringing.
column3: His face expressed attention and expectation, intent but timid and cringing.

column2: Haven't you something more to say--something to add? could be read in the intent gaze he fixed on Ivan.
column3: Haven't you something more to say-something to add? could be read in the intent gaze he fixed on Ivan.

column2: And couldn't I be sent for from Tchermashnya, too--in case anything happened? Ivan shouted suddenly, for some unknown reason raising his voice.
column3: And couldn't I be sent for from Tchermashnya, too-in case anything happened? Ivan shouted suddenly, for some unknown reason raising his voice.

column2: From Tchermashnya, too ... you could be sent for, Smerdyakov muttered, almost in a whisper, looking disconcerted, but gazing intently into Ivan's eyes.
column3: From Tchermashnya, too ... you could be sent for, Smerdyakov muttered, almost in a whisper, looking disconcerted, but gazing intently into Ivan's eyes.

column2: Only Moscow is farther and Tchermashnya is nearer.	Only Moscow is farther and Tchermashnya is nearer.
column3: true

column2: Is it to save my spending money on the fare, or to save my going so far out of my way, that you insist on Tchermashnya?"
column3: Is it to save my spending money on the fare, or to save my going so far out of my way, that you insist on Tchermashnya?"

column2: Precisely so ... muttered Smerdyakov, with a breaking voice.
column3: Precisely so ... muttered Smerdyakov, with a breaking voice.

column2: He looked at Ivan with a revolting smile, and again made ready to draw back.
column3: He looked at Ivan with a revolting smile, and again made ready to draw back.

column2: But to his astonishment Ivan broke into a laugh, and went through the gate still laughing.
column3: But to his astonishment Ivan broke into a laugh, and went through the gate still laughing.

column2: Any one who had seen his face at that moment would have known that he was not laughing from lightness of heart, and he could not have explained himself what he was feeling at that instant.
column3: Any one who had seen his face at that moment would have known that he was not laughing from lightness of heart, and he could not have explained himself what he was feeling at that instant.

column2: He moved and walked as though in a nervous frenzy.
column3: He moved and walked as though in a nervous frenzy.
